questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.correct_answer: A. Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children with bacterial meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Haemophilus influenzae should be isolated for 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic therapy to prevent transmission.

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IVIG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical features of Kawasaki disease, including fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and skin peeling. Understand the importance of prompt treatment with IVIG and aspirin to reduce the risk of coronary artery complications in Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a pediatric vasculitis, and early intervention is critical for a positive outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD

options.label: D
options.text: Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for age less than -3 SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition is defined by weight-for-height less than -3 SD, MUAC < 115 mm, or the presence of bilateral pedal edema, but not by weight-for-age less than -3 SD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Noonan Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abnormal Karyotype

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Noonan Syndrome, often referred to as the "male Turner Syndrome," does not typically involve an abnormal karyotype, which distinguishes it from Turner's Syndrome. Individuals with Noonan Syndrome usually have a normal karyotype (46,XY or 46,XX), meaning their chromosome count and structure are typical, but they exhibit phenotypic characteristics similar to those of Turner's Syndrome due to a genetic mutation affecting the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Short Stature: Incorrect as an option because short stature is a common feature of Noonan Syndrome, associated with its genetic profile.
  • • Option A. Short Stature:
  • • Option B. Webbed Neck: Incorrect as an option because a webbed neck is also a typical phenotypic characteristic of Noonan Syndrome.
  • • Option B. Webbed Neck:
  • • Option C. Low Posterior Hairline: Incorrect as an option because this is another feature that Noonan Syndrome shares with Turner’s Syndrome, reflecting similar phenotypic expressions.
  • • Option C. Low Posterior Hairline:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noonan Syndrome is characterized by typical phenotypic features such as short stature, webbed neck, and low posterior hairline but with a normal chromosomal karyotype, unlike Turner’s Syndrome which involves an abnormal karyotype.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following denotes an "infant at risk"? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Mother who has not taken folic acid during pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Infant with history of premature birth < 32 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An infant born before 32 weeks of gestation is considered high-risk due to the increased likelihood of complications associated with prematurity.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac conditions does not typically result in enlargement of the left atrium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atrial septal defect

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of an atrial septal defect (ASD), the primary issue is the presence of an opening between the left and right atria, allowing blood to flow from the left to the right atrium due to the higher pressure in the left atrium. This condition leads to enlargement of the right atrium and right ventricle as they handle increased blood volume. However, the left atrium is not typically enlarged in uncomplicated cases of ASD because the blood is shunted away from it, reducing its workload rather than increasing it. Enlargement of the left atrium may occur in advanced stages such as with the development of Eisenmenger's syndrome, where a reversal of the shunt occurs, but this is not the initial presentation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ventricular septal defect: As it often leads to increased blood flow through the lungs and back into the left atrium, potentially causing its enlargement.
  • • Option
  • • A. Ventricular septal defect:
  • • Option C. Aortopulmonary window: This condition creates abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and subsequent left atrial enlargement due to increased pulmonary venous return.
  • • Option
  • • C. Aortopulmonary window:
  • • Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus: As it generally involves increased pulmonary circulation that returns to the left atrium, causing its potential enlargement due to the increased volume of blood it must handle.
  • • Option
  • • D. Patent ductus arteriosus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrial septal defect (ASD) typically does not result in enlargement of the left atrium in its initial stages because it decreases the volume and pressure load on the left atrium by allowing blood to flow to the right atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: Which of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-ray except: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulmonary venous hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/ML (N 43, L 54, and E3). Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis can cause neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia, typically presenting with an insidious onset of cough, tachypnea, absence of fever, and peripheral eosinophilia in infants aged 1 to 3 months.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity? (AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: D
options.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of more than 50% orange cells in the Nile blue test indicates fetal lung maturity, whereas more than 50% blue cells suggest immaturity.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.

options.label: B
options.text: Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.

options.label: C
options.text: Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.correct_answer: A. Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child with some dehydration, the recommended treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding, with instructions to return if danger signs develop.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus
  • ➤ Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • ➤ Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • ➤ Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and skinny appearance. Which of the following condition best fit the diagnosis? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Marasmus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, leading to a very thin, emaciated appearance in affected children.

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

questions.text: In PALS ABCDE all pairs are matched correctly except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) D for dehydration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In PALS, the "D" in the ABCDE mnemonic stands for Disability, which involves assessing the child’s neurological status.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 infection targets erythroid cell lines, particularly the pronormoblast stage, and is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders, as well as other clinical manifestations such as erythema infectiosum, arthritis, and non-immune fetal hydrops.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: CFTR gene mutation is associated with which channels? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CFTR gene mutation causes a defect in chloride channels, leading to elevated sweat chloride levels, which is a key diagnostic feature of Cystic Fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma

options.label: D
options.text: They are associated with a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with facial angiofibroma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is associated with for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is seen in characteristic of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF1.

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Head only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopagus is a specific type of conjoined twins where the fusion occurs only at the cranium (head), and these twins are genetically identical and of the same sex.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of prognosis in neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pulmonary hypertension

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most critical determinant of prognosis in congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is the degree of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension results from the underdevelopment of the pulmonary vasculature, which is a consequence of pulmonary hypoplasia. This condition leads to increased pulmonary vascular resistance, which significantly impacts the neonate's ability to oxygenate blood effectively and is a major factor in morbidity and mortality associated with CDH.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Delay in surgery: While important, surgical timing is less critical than the underlying pulmonary condition.
  • • Option B. Delay in surgery:
  • • Option C. Size of defect: Although it plays a role, it is not as predictive of outcome as pulmonary hypertension.
  • • Option C. Size of defect:
  • • Option D. Gestational age at diagnosis: Early detection can indicate severity, but the degree of pulmonary hypertension remains the most critical factor.
  • • Option D. Gestational age at diagnosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most important prognostic factor in congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the degree of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management which of the following needs to be given? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate airway management and empirical antibiotic therapy, with IV Ceftriaxone being the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about congenital CMV infection? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic

options.label: B
options.text: Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life

options.label: D
options.text: If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.correct_answer: D. If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal IgG positivity for CMV suggests a lower risk of congenital CMV transmission, making it less likely for the fetus to develop the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022) Age < 1 year Temperature of 38-39°C Duration of fever < 24 h Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection

options.label: B
options.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

options.label: C
options.text: Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection

options.label: D
options.text: Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia, raised creatinine levels, and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Brain Growth max at 2 years Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years
  • ➤ Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • ➤ Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • ➤ Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • ➤ Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • ➤ Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years
  • ➤ Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022) Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor. Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.

options.label: B
options.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022) Bronchoscopy Computed tomography scan ICD insertion Chest x-ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A premature baby, born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1500 grams has stable vitals. What is the initial feeding method of choice? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.correct_answer: C. Orogastric tube / Alternative oral route
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube / Alternative oral route

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a premature baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with stable vitals, the preferred initial feeding method is oral feeding by spoon, paladai, or cup. If the baby cannot take an adequate amount of feeding by these methods, orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding should be initiated. This approach ensures that the baby receives sufficient nutrition while accommodating their developmental feeding abilities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Intravenous fluids: Typically used for extremely premature infants or those unable to tolerate enteral feeding.
  • • Option A. Intravenous fluids:
  • • Option B. Intravenous fluids and oral feeding: This combination may be used in specific cases but is not the first choice for stable preterm infants at 33 weeks.
  • • Option
  • • B. Intravenous fluids and oral feeding:
  • • Option D. Total parenteral nutrition: Generally reserved for infants who cannot tolerate enteral feeding.
  • • Option D. Total parenteral nutrition:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable preterm infants born at 33 weeks, the initial feeding method of choice is orogastric tube or alternative oral routes such as spoon, paladai, or cup feeding.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 21%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased urine bilirubin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Rh incompatibility, increased urine bilirubin is unlikely due to the immaturity of the newborn's liver enzymes needed for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) postnatally is the most important factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A child has features of meningitis with following CSF examination: protein=93, glucose=20, Lymphocytes + Diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the CSF findings associated with different types of meningitis. Understand that the CSF profile, including elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis, can be indicative of tubercular meningitis. Be aware of the various etiologies and clinical presentations of meningitis in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress. Chest X ray reveals air bubbles in the left hemithorax. What is your best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urine examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to term baby in first 24 hours after delivery? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 60ml/kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate amount of milk or fluid to be given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery is 60 ml per kg of body weight.

questions.text: A child has presented with a birth defect as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Craniorachischisis with anencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect involving both the brain and spinal cord, with the worst prognosis among neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta, in contrast, has the best prognosis among these conditions.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine is the most appropriate sample for the detection of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection using PCR, particularly in the neonatal period.

questions.text: After how many seconds of chest compressions and bag and mask ventilation, should we start the adrenaline? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 60 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenaline should be administered when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023) RBS → 550 рН → 7.01 Na+ → 158 Urine glucose → 3+ Urine Ketone → +ve

options.label: A
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: C
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: D
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.correct_answer: A. Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text: What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023) Systolic mumur Grade 3 Diastolic murmur Abnormal second heart sound Abnormal BP
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.
